The strand-displacement mechanism of Bacillus subtilis phage φ29 DNA replication occurs through replicative intermediates with high amounts of single-stranded DNA (ssDNA). These ssDNA must be covered by the viral ssDNA-binding protein, φ29 SSB, to be replicated in vivo. To understand the characteristics of φ29 SSB-ssDNA complex that could explain the requirement of φ29 SSB, we have (i) determined the hydrodynamic behavior of φ29 SSB in solution and (ii) monitored the effect of complex formation on φ29 SSB and ssDNA secondary structure. Based on its translational frictional coefficient (3.5 ± 0.1) × 108 gs−1, and its rotational correlation time, 7.0 ± 0.5 ns, φ29 SSB was modeled as a nearly spherical ellipsoid of revolution. The axial ratio (p = a/b) could range from 0.8 to 1.0 (oblate model, a < b) or 1.0 to 3.2 (prolate model, a > b). Far-UV CD spectra, indicated that φ29 SSB is highly organized within a wide range of temperatures (15 to 50°C), being mainly constituted by β-sheet elements (∼50%, at pH 7). Complex formation with ssDNA, although inducing minimal changes on the global conformation of φ29 SSB, had a clear stabilizing effect against pH and temperature increase of the solution samples. On the other hand, φ29 SSB binding leads to non-conservative changes of the near-UV CD spectra of ssDNA, which are consistent with different nearest-neighbor interactions of the nucleotide bases upon complex formation. The above results will be compared to those reported for other SSBs and discussed in terms of the functional roles of φ29 SSB. Complex formation with ssDNA, although inducing minimal changes on the global conformation of φ29 SSB, had a clear stabilizing effect against pH and temperature increase of the solution samples. On the other hand, φ29 SSB binding leads to non-conservative changes of the near-UV CD spectra of ssDNA, which are consistent with different nearest-neighbor interactions of the nucleotide bases upon complex formation. The above results will be compared to those reported for other SSBs and discussed in terms of the functional roles of φ29 SSB. In all organisms studied so far, key cellular processes related to DNA metabolism, such as DNA replication, DNA repair, DNA recombination, or DNA transcription, occur via transient ssDNA 1The abbreviations used are: ssDNAsingle-stranded DNASSB(s)single-stranded DNA-binding protein(s)Ff SSBSSBs of Escherichia coli phages M13, fd, and pf1T4 gp32phage T4 SSBT7 gp2.5phage T7 SSBN4 SSBphage N4 SSBKeffeffective ssDNA binding constantωcooperativity parameter of ssDNA binding process. intermediates whose structure must be properly organized. This organization is achieved and maintained by highly efficient, localized (sequence-specific), or generalized (sequence-independent) protein contacts. Noncatalytic proteins that bind ssDNA with a relatively high affinity in a sequence independent manner have been referred to as single-stranded DNA-binding proteins, SSBs, (1Kowalczykowski S.C. Bear D.G. von Hippel P.H. The Enzymes. 1981; 14: 373-444Google Scholar, 2Chase J.W. Williams K.R. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1986; 55: 103-136Google Scholar, 3Kneale G.G. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 1992; 2: 124-130Google Scholar, 4Kornberg A. Baker T.A. Kornberg A. Baker T.A. DNA Replication. W. H. Freeman & Co., San Francisco1992: 323-354Google Scholar). One of the most striking features of the SSBs is the lack of any clear structural common characteristics among them. Thus, the oligomeric state of these proteins in solution is highly variable. They have being found as monomers, e.g. N4 SSB (5Lindberg G. Kowalczykowski S.C. Rist J.K. Sugino A. Rhotman-Denes L. J. Mol. Biol. 1989; 264: 12700-12708Google Scholar); φ29 SSB (6Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar); dimers, e.g. SSBs from filamentous Fd phages (3Kneale G.G. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 1992; 2: 124-130Google Scholar); T7 gene 2.5 (7Kim C. Synder R.O. Wold M.S. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1992; 12: 3050-3059Google Scholar); tetramers, e.g. Escherichia coli SSB (8Meyer R.R. Laine P.S. Microbiol. Rev. 1990; 54: 342-380Google Scholar); multioligomers, T4 gp32 (1Kowalczykowski S.C. Bear D.G. von Hippel P.H. The Enzymes. 1981; 14: 373-444Google Scholar); or hetero-oligomers, e.g. human SSB (9Wold M.S. Kelly T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 2523-2527Google Scholar) and Drosophila SSB (10Mitsis P.G. Kowalczykowski S.C. Lehman I.R. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 5257-5266Google Scholar). Moreover, although several attempts to find structural motifs in SSBs have been made (11Prasad B.V.V. Chiu W. J. Mol. Biol. 1987; 193: 579-584Google Scholar, 12Gutiérrez C. Martín G. Sogo J.M. Salas M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 2104-2111Google Scholar), only among SSBs of very related filamentous phages a limited sequence homology has been found within the so-called DNA binding wing (see 3Kneale G.G. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 1992; 2: 124-130Google Scholar, for review). NMR and crystallographic studies showed a similar three-dimensional structure of the SSBs of E. coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa filamentous phages Ff and Pf3 (13Skinner M.M. Zhang H. Leschnitzer D.H. Guan Y. Bellamy H. Sweet R.M. Gray C.W. Konings R.N.H. Wang A.H.J. Terwilliger T.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 2071-2075Google Scholar, 14Folkers P.J.M. Nilges M. Folmer R.H.A. Konings R.N.H. Hilbers C.W. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 236: 229-246Google Scholar, 15Folmer R.H.A. Nilges M. Konings R.N.H. Hilbers C.W. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 4132-4142Google Scholar), rather different from that of T4 gp32, the other SSB 2Adenovirus DBP, whose three-dimensional structure has been recently resolved by x-ray difraction (16Stuiver M.H. Bergsma W.G. Arnber A.C. van Amerongen H. van Grondelle R. van der Vliet P.C. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 255: 999-1011Google Scholar) is not considered as a SSB sensu stricto since is able to bind both, ssDNA and dsDNA, with high affinity (17Tucker P.A. Tsernoglou D. Tucker A.D. Coenjaerts F.E.J. Leenders H. van der Vliet P.C. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 2994-3002Google Scholar). whose structure (x-ray difraction) has been reported (18Shamoo Y. Friedman A.M. Parsons M.R. Konigsberg W.H. Steitz T.A. Nature. 1995; 376: 362-366Google Scholar). In addition, detailed analysis of a few SSB-ssDNA complexes indicate that each protein interacts with ssDNA using a particular set of residues (3Kneale G.G. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 1992; 2: 124-130Google Scholar, 15Folmer R.H.A. Nilges M. Konings R.N.H. Hilbers C.W. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 4132-4142Google Scholar, 19Folmer R.H.A. Nilges M. Folkers P.J.M. Konings R.N.H. Hilbers C.W. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 240: 341-357Google Scholar, 20Casas-Finet J.R. Karpel R.L. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 9735-9744Google Scholar, 21Lohman T.M. Ferrari M.E. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 527-5701Google Scholar) and induces different conformational changes in the DNA structure (see 2Chase J.W. Williams K.R. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1986; 55: 103-136Google Scholar, 4Kornberg A. Baker T.A. Kornberg A. Baker T.A. DNA Replication. W. H. Freeman & Co., San Francisco1992: 323-354Google Scholar, and 8Meyer R.R. Laine P.S. Microbiol. Rev. 1990; 54: 342-380Google Scholar, for reviews). The functional characteristics of the SSBs complicate even more this variability. Most of the SSBs activate DNA replication, e.g. E. coli SSB, T4 gp32, T7 gene 2.5 protein, φ29 SSB, and human SSB (reviewed in 4Kornberg A. Baker T.A. Kornberg A. Baker T.A. DNA Replication. W. H. Freeman & Co., San Francisco1992: 323-354Google Scholar). However, other SSBs, as those of the filamentous phages, block DNA replication (22Salstrom J.S. Pratt D. J. Mol. Biol. 1971; 61: 489-501Google Scholar). As a consequence of this diversity, the molecular nature of the SSB-ssDNA interactions is not yet well understood. single-stranded DNA single-stranded DNA-binding protein(s) SSBs of Escherichia coli phages M13, fd, and pf1 phage T4 SSB phage T7 SSB phage N4 SSB effective ssDNA binding constant cooperativity parameter of ssDNA binding process. The requirement for a SSB is particularly important during strand-displacement DNA replication, where great amounts of ssDNA are produced. This ssDNA corresponds to the strand that is not used as template and is displaced as the DNA polymerase progresses. One of the best characterized strand-displacement DNA replication systems is that of Bacillus subtilis phage φ29 (see 23Salas M. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1991; 60: 39-71Google Scholar, 24Salas M. Freire R. Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Méndez J. Bravo A. Serrano M. Blasco M.A. Blanco L. Gutiérrez C. Hermoso J.M. FEMS Microbiol. Rev. 1995; 17: 73-82Google Scholar, 25Salas M. Rojo F. Hoch J.A. Losick R. Bacillus subtilis and Other Gram-positive Bacteria: Biochemistry, Physiology and Molecular Genetics. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1993: 843-845Google Scholar, for reviews). In vivo, φ29 DNA replication cannot procced in the absence of the viral product of gene 5, the viral SSB (12Gutiérrez C. Martín G. Sogo J.M. Salas M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 2104-2111Google Scholar, 26Martín G. Lázaro J.M. Méndez E. Salas M. Nucleic Acids Res. 1989; 17: 3663-3672Google Scholar). φ29 SSB is an extremely abundant protein in infected cells (∼2.5 × 106 copies/cell), representing ∼3% of the total protein content (26Martín G. Lázaro J.M. Méndez E. Salas M. Nucleic Acids Res. 1989; 17: 3663-3672Google Scholar). In vitro, φ29 SSB stimulates DNA replication, at least at two levels: (i) by increasing the amount of dNTP incorporated (12Gutiérrez C. Martín G. Sogo J.M. Salas M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 2104-2111Google Scholar, 26Martín G. Lázaro J.M. Méndez E. Salas M. Nucleic Acids Res. 1989; 17: 3663-3672Google Scholar) and (ii) by increasing the DNA elongation velocity of φ29 DNA polymerase under conditions in which the DNA opening is impaired (27Soengas M.S. Gutiérrez C. Salas M. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 253: 517-529Google Scholar). This activity has been proposed to be related to the helix-destabilizing properties of φ29 SSB (27Soengas M.S. Gutiérrez C. Salas M. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 253: 517-529Google Scholar). φ29 SSB becomes essential for in vitro viral DNA replication when the amount of DNA is reduced (28Blanco L. Lázaro J.M. de Vega M. Bonnin A. Salas M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 12198-12202Google Scholar), the closest condition to the initial steps of the viral infection. φ29 SSB binds to ssDNA in a cooperative way (Keff = 105M−1, ω = 50-70) covering 3-4 nucleotides per monomer, likely as a single array of protein units along the ssDNA (6Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar). When visualized by electron microscopy, the φ29 SSB-DNA complex shows a continuous and homogeneous structure, and nucleosome-like structures were not apparent (6Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar, 12Gutiérrez C. Martín G. Sogo J.M. Salas M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 2104-2111Google Scholar). Protein binding induces a 50% reduction in ssDNA length (29Gutiérrez C. Sogo J.M. Salas M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 222: 983-994Google Scholar) and a 95% reduction of the intrinsic tyrosine fluorescence emission of the protein (6Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar). This observation has been the starting point for the analysis of φ29 SSB ssDNA binding domain as described in the accompanying paper (30Soengas M.S. Mateo R.C. Salas M. Acuña A.U. Gutiérrez C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 295-302Google Scholar). The functional requirement of φ29 SSB during the DNA replication stage of φ29 infective cycle might be related to the structural properties of φ29 SSB that would lead to a particular organization of complex with the ssDNA of the replicative intermediates. In this paper, we have analyzed the global conformation of φ29 SSB in solution by analytical ultracentrifugation, steady-state and time-resolved fluorescence anisotropy measurements. Conformational changes in the protein and ssDNA structure induced upon complex formation were studied by means of circular dichroism techniques. The results of these studies indicate that φ29 SSB differs markedly from other well known SSBs. All the solutions were made with distilled, deionized (MilliQ) and sterilized water, and finally filtered through 0.45-μm filters using a Millex-HA Filter Unit (Millipore). The buffer used in analytical ultracentrifugation, time-resolved fluorescence, and circular dichroism (CD) analysis was 5 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5 (20°C) (buffer A), while the buffer used in steady state fluorescence studies was 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5 (20°C), 4% glycerol (buffer B). M13mp18 ssDNA was from Boehringer Mannheim and oligonucleotides dT20, dA16, and polynucleotides poly(dT300) and poly(dA300) from Pharmacia Biotech Inc. Nucleotide concentrations were quantified as indicated by the supplier. φ29 SSB was purified by differential ammonium sulfate fractionation of φ29-infected cellular extracts and further phosphocelulose and DEAE-cellulose chromatography, essentially as described (27Soengas M.S. Gutiérrez C. Salas M. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 253: 517-529Google Scholar). Protein concentration was estimated by the Lowry method (31Lowry O.H. Rosebrough N.J. Farr A.L. Randall R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1951; 193: 265-275Google Scholar), using bovine serum albumin as a standard. Analytical ultracentrifugation experiments were carried out in an Optima XL-A analytical ultracentrifuge (Beckman Instruments Inc.) equipped with a UV-VIS optical scanner, using a Ti60 rotor and double sector 12-mm centerpieces of epon charcoal. In sedimentation equilibrium measurements, samples of φ29 SSB ranging from 10 to 30 μM were centrifuged in buffer A at 20°C and at two speeds, 25,000 and 30,000 rpm. When sedimentation equilibrium was reached, absorbance scans (at 230 nm) were taken as a function of radial distance. The base-line offsets were determined by scanning the samples at a higher speed (42,000 rpm). To obtain the relative molecular weight (Mr) of φ29 SSB, the experimental data were fitted to the equation which describes the radial distribution of concentration of an ideal solute at sedimentation equilibrium (see, for example, 32Minton A.P. Schuster T.M. Laue T.M. Modern Analytical Ultracentrifugation. Brikhäuser, Boston1994: 81-93Google Scholar) using the programs XLAEQ and EQASSOC (supplied by Beckman; see 33van Holde K.E. Physical Biochemistry. Prentice-Hall, Inc., New York1985: 225-291Google Scholar). The value of the partial specific volume of φ29 SSB was estimated from its amino acid composition (34Laue T.M. Shah B.D. Ridgeway T.M. Pelletier S.L. Harding S.E. Horton H.C. Rowe A.J. Analytical Ultracentrifugation in Biochemistry and Polymer Science. Royal Society of Chemistry, Cambridge1993: 90-125Google Scholar) as 0.739 ml g−1. In velocity sedimentation experiments, φ29 SSB (ranging in concentration from 10 to 30 μM) was centrifuged at 60,000 rpm and 20°C and radial scans at 230 nm were taken at 10-min intervals during 3 h. The analysis of the experimental data was performed in two ways: (i) by taking the derivative of the absorbance data to calculate the peak of the moving boundary (XLAVEL program, supplied by Beckman), and (ii) by using the second moment analysis of Goldberg (35Goldberg R.J. J. Phys. Chem. 1953; 57: 194Google Scholar) to locate the boundary position (VELGAMMA program, Beckman). The rate of the motion of the boundary was used for the estimation of the sedimentation coefficient. This value was corrected to standard conditions (water, 20°C; 33) to obtain the s20,w values. The translational frictional coefficient, f, of φ29 SSB was obtained by the classical Svedberg equation (see 36Waxman E. Laws W. Laue T.M. Emerson Y. Ross A.B.A. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 3005-3012Google Scholar for review), f=Mr(1−vρ)NAs(Eq. 1) whereMr stands for the molecular weight of the protein obtained for equilibrium ultracentrifugation, is the solvent density, and N A is the Avogadro's constant. The global conformation of Ï†29 SSB in solution was modeled with rigid ellipsoids of revolution (the axis being a, b = c). Two models were considered, the prolate ellipsoid, in which a > b, and the oblate ellipsoid, characterized by a < b. In both cases, the rotational parameters of the protein are related to the hydrated protein volume V and asymmetry (given by the axial ratio p = a/b) in the following way, V=KTϕglobal 6η4gperp +2gpar (Eq. 2) where Ï†global stands for the rotational correlation time of the decay of the anisotropy assigned to the global motion of the entire protein (37Wahl P.H. Cundall R.B. Dale R.E. Time-resolved Fluorescence Spectroscopy in Biochemistry and Biology. Plenum Press, New York1983Google Scholar, 38Montejo J.M. Navqi K.R. Lillo M.P. González J. Acuña A.U. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 7580-7586Google Scholar, 39Steel C. Naqvi R.K. J. Phys. Chem. 1995; 95: 10713-10718Google Scholar), Î· is the solution viscosity, and gpar and gperp are rotational Perrin factors depending only on p (40Perrin F. J. Phys. Radium. 1936; 7: 1-11Google Scholar, 41Cantor C.R. Shimmel P.R. Biophysical Chemistry, Part II. Freeman W. H. and Co., San Francisco1980Google Scholar). The gpar and gperp values were calculated as gpar =2p2−1/3p(p−s)(Eq. 3) gperp =2p4−1/3p2p2−1s−p(Eq. 4) s=p2−1−1/2lnp+p2−11/2(Eq. 5) s=q2−1−1/2ATNq2−11/2( where q=1/p)(Eq. 6) for the oblate ellipsoid model. The experimentally determined value of Ï†global (7.0 Â± 0.5 ns; see 30Soengas M.S. Mateo R.C. Salas M. Acuña A.U. Gutiérrez C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 295-302Google Scholar) was introduced for axial ratio ranging from 0.1 to 1 (oblate model) and 1 to 10 (prolate model), in Equation 2 to obtain the V values of the set of ellipsoids compatible with the experimental rotational parameters. The theoretical translational frictional coefficient, ftheo corresponding to each of these ellipsoids was obtained as 6Ï€Î·RsphF. Where Rsph stands for the radius of a sphere with the same volume V as the ellipsoid, and F is the translational Perrin factor whose value also depend on p (41Cantor C.R. Shimmel P.R. Biophysical Chemistry, Part II. Freeman W. H. and Co., San Francisco1980Google Scholar). The F values for the prolate and oblate ellipsoids, Fobl and Fpro, respectively, where calculated as, Fobl=1−q21/2q2/3ln1+1−q21/2q(Eq. 7) Fpro=q2−11/2q2/3ATN1−q21/2(Eq. 8) where q = 1/p. The comparison of the experimentally determined fobs and the estimated ftheo provides the range of ellipsoids compatible with the translational and rotational hydrodynamic behavior of φ29 SSB. The hydration extent of the protein, Δ (gram of H2O/g of protein) was estimated as Δ = (V − Vanh)/Vanh, where Vanh (estimated from Ranh = 0.723 × 10−8 Mr(null)/1;3; see 36Waxman E. Laws W. Laue T.M. Emerson Y. Ross A.B.A. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 3005-3012Google Scholar for further details) corresponds to the anhydrous volume of a sphere whose Mr is that of φ29 SSB. CD spectra were recorded on a Jasco Model J-700, at 0.2-nm intervals and, unless otherwise stated, at 25°C and at a scan speed of 20 nm/min. The absorbance of the samples was kept below 0.1 over the measuring range. φ29 SSB (6.5 μM) CD spectra were obtained with 0.1-cm cells in the absence and presence of an excess of ssDNA (350 μM nucleotide). DNA binding was tested by parallel measurements of the quenching of the intrinsic protein fluorescence upon DNA addition as described previously (6Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar). When required, small amounts of 2.5 M NaOH from a concentrated stock were added to the indicated amount of free or bound φ29 SSB (the volume change at the end of the titration was <1%), the pH being simultaneously measured. The effect of temperature on the protein conformational stability was analyzed by recording the spectra after maintaining the protein or protein-ssDNA solution for 5 min at the different temperatures. Controls were made to ensure that the variations in the pH due to temperature change did not affect the far-UV CD spectra of the protein. Plotted CD data, as mean residue ellipticity, corresponded to an average of three scans. Corrections for the contribution of the buffer and DNA to the optical activity were made when necessary. The relative amount of α-helix, β-sheet, and β-turns of φ29 SSB where estimated with the CONTIN (version 2) program (42Provencher, S. W., (1984) EMBL Technical Report DAO7.Google Scholar) by fitting the φ29 SSB spectra, between 190 and 240 nm, to those of 16 proteins of known secondary structure (43Chang T.C. Wu C.C.-S. Yang J.T. Anal. Biochem. 1978; 91: 13-31Google Scholar) as outlined by Provencher and Glöckner (44Provencher S.W. Glöckner J. Biochemistry. 1981; 20: 33-37Google Scholar). Alternatively, convex constraint analysis, as described by the Fasman group (45Perczel A. Hollósi M. Tusnády G. Fasman G.D. Protein Eng. 1991; 4: 669-679Google Scholar, 46Perczel A. Park K. Fasman G.D. Proteins Struct. Funct. Genet. 1992; 13: 57-69Google Scholar), were also made, but the best fits were not so accurate. ssDNA spectra (dT20, dA16, poly(dT), or poly(dA)) were recorded in buffer A, with 1-cm path length cells. Five scans were averaged and the data were plotted as ϵL−ϵR (Δϵ) per mol of nucleotide. Stacking interactions between neighboring nucleotides were analyzed by increasing the temperature of the solution. Spectra were taken after keeping ssDNA samples 5 min at the desired temperature. To analyze the effect of φ29 SSB binding on the ssDNA structure, spectra were recorded after adding small aliquots of a concentrated protein stock (∼7 mg/ml) to a fixed amount of the indicated ssDNA (∼110 μM nucleotide). Buffer and protein optical activity were substracted to obtain the corrected ssDNA spectra. Saturation was considered to be reached when further protein addition did not induce any change in CD spectra. The nucleotide site size, that is, the number of nucleotides covered by a protein monomer, was calculated from the ratio DNA/SSB that induced the maximal change at wavelengths corresponding to the maximal activity of free ssDNA. Steady-state measurements of the intrinsic fluorescence of φ29 SSB were performed at 25°C in a SLM-8000D photon counting L-format fluorimeter fitted with Glan-Thompson polarizers at λexc = 276 nm and λem = 308 nm (slits set to 2 and 4 nm, respectively; 47Mateo C.R. Lillo M.P. González-Rodríguez J. Acuña A.U. Eur. Biophys. J. 1991; 20: 41-52Google Scholar). The anisotropy, <r>, of φ29 SSB fluoresence emission was obtained as described in the accompanying paper (30Soengas M.S. Mateo R.C. Salas M. Acuña A.U. Gutiérrez C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 295-302Google Scholar). Complex formation with ssDNA was monitored by measuring the increase in steady-state anisotropy together with the quenching of the fluorescence emission at magic angle (I54) and during reverse titrations of a fixed amount of φ29 SSB (10 μM) with increasing quantities of ssDNA. Corrections for dilution and inner filter effect due to ssDNA absorption were made when necessary as described previously (6Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar). The solution conformation of φ29 SSB was approached by analyzing hydrodynamic parameters directly dependent on the protein aggregation state, size, and shape. The initial step in the modeling process was the estimation, by analytical ultracentrifugation techniques (sedimentation equilibrium and sedimentation velocity), of the molecular weight and the sedimentation and frictional coefficients of φ29 SSB. Open table in a new tab The experimental data corresponding to the radial distribution of φ29 SSB concentration after sedimentation equilibrium were best fitted to equations described for a monomeric behavior of a protein. An example for 12 μM SSB centrifuged at 30,000 rpm is depicted in Fig. 1. The fitting procedures (χ2 = 6.4 × 10−3) gave an average of 13,600 ± 400, for the Mr of φ29 SSB, very close to the calculated from its amino acid composition (13,343; see 26Martín G. Lázaro J.M. Méndez E. Salas M. Nucleic Acids Res. 1989; 17: 3663-3672Google Scholar). This confirms the results previously obtained with indirect techniques (gel filtration chromatography; 6Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar), and therefore, φ29 SSB can be confidently considered as a monomer in solution, at least in the concentration range used for the analysis of its functional activities and ssDNA binding properties. Sedimentation velocity experiments were carried out to determine the sedimentation and diffusion coefficients, s20,w and D20,w, respectively. The sedimentation process of a 60,000 rpm centrifugation of φ29 SSB was analyzed by following the movement of the boundary as described elsewhere (see 48Hansen J.C. Lebowitz J. Demeler B. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 13155-13163Google Scholar, for a review). For the above indicated protein range, the estimated s20,w and D20,w (procedures not shown) were 1.7 ± 0.1 S and (1.18 ± 0.07) × 10−6 cm2 s−1, respectively. By including the Mr and s20,w values in the Svedberg equation (see “Materials and Methods,”Equation 1) the translational frictional coefficient, fobs, was computed as (3.5 ± 0.1) × 108 gs−1 (Table I). It is well known that the value of the frictional coefficient does not allow, by itself, the distinction between a symmetric but rigid structure from a highly asymmetric but flexible conformations (see for examples, 36Waxman E. In primary embryonal fibroblasts from transgenic mice expressing H-2 genes and a miniature swine class I transgene (PD1), transformation with the highly oncogenic Ad12 results in a reduction in peptide transporter and proteasome-associated (LMP2 and LMP7) gene expression, and suppression in transport and cell surface expression of all class I antigens. The selective suppression in transport of H-2 (but not of PD1) molecules in cells reconstituted for the expression of peptide transporter and LMP genes implied that an additional factor(s) is involved in the assembly of class I complexes. Here we show that the β2m, H-2Db, and H-2Kb genes are transcribed and translated in Ad12-transformed cells. However, unlike normal and E1Ad5-transformed cells, in which β2m is either secreted unbound or bound to class I heavy chains, in Ad12-transformed cells significant amounts of β2m are retained in the cell bound to the membrane, but free of class I heavy chains. This abnormal turnover of β2m in the Ad12-transformed cells suggests the existence of a novel β2m-binding molecule(s) that sequesters β2m, and this process may provide a mechanism by which transformation with Ad12 may subvert class I complex formation. The selective suppression in transport of H-2 (but not of PD1) molecules in cells reconstituted for the expression of peptide transporter and LMP genes implied that an additional factor(s) is involved in the assembly of class I complexes. Here we show that the β2m, H-2Db, and H-2Kb genes are transcribed and translated in Ad12-transformed cells. However, unlike normal and E1Ad5-transformed cells, in which β2m is either secreted unbound or bound to class I heavy chains, in Ad12-transformed cells significant amounts of β2m are retained in the cell bound to the membrane, but free of class I heavy chains. This abnormal turnover of β2m in the Ad12-transformed cells suggests the existence of a novel β2m-binding molecule(s) that sequesters β2m, and this process may provide a mechanism by which transformation with Ad12 may subvert class I complex formation. Doherty P.C. Adv. Immunol. 1979; 22: 51-177Google Scholar). This mechanism enables the immune system to control infectious diseases and the growth of tumor cells (2Goodenow R.S. Vogel J.M. Linsk R.L. Science. 1985; 230: 777-783Google Scholar, 3Hämmerling G.J. Klar D. Pulm W. Momburg F. Moldenhauer G. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1987; 179: 245-259Google Scholar). Indeed, cells infected by a variety of viruses that interfere with cell surface expression of class I antigens, as well as tumors of various origins that demonstrate suppressed levels of class I antigens, can escape immune surveillance (4Ehrlich R. Res. 1995; 14: 77-97Google Scholar). major histocompatibility complex transporter associated with antigen presentation endoplasmic reticulum phosphate-buffered saline endoglycosidase H polymerase chain reaction reverse transcription-PCR L, phosphostimulated luminescence low molecular The biochemistry and cell biology of antigen processing and presentation by class I MHC molecules has been analyzed in detail in recent years (5Yewdell J.W. Bennink J.R. Adv. Immunol. 1992; 52: 1-123Google Scholar, 6Germain R.N. Margulies D.H. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1993; 11: 403-450Google Scholar). It is well established that the efficient transport of class I molecules to the cell surface depends on the assembly of the heavy chain/β2m dimer with peptides that are usually 8-9 amino acids long. Such peptides, generated by cleavage of proteins in the cytosol, are actively transported by a heterodimeric complex, known as transporter associated with antigen presentation (TAP), into the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), where assembly with class I molecules takes place. The trimeric complex is then transported through the Golgi apparatus to the cell surface. Mutant cell lines (5Yewdell J.W. Bennink J.R. Adv. Immunol. 1992; 52: 1-123Google Scholar, 6Germain R.N. Margulies D.H. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1993; 11: 403-450Google Scholar, 7Spies T. DeMars R. Nature. 1991; 351: 323-324Google Scholar, 8Attaya M. Jameson S. Martinez C.K. Hermel E. Aldrich C. Forman J. Fischer Lindahl K. Bevan M.J. Monaco J.J. Nature. 1992; 355: 647-649Google Scholar), “knockout” mice (9Van Kaer L. Ashton-Rickardt P.G. Ploegh H.L. Tonegawa S. Cell. 1992; 71: 1205-1214Google Scholar, 10Arnold D. Driscoll J. Androlewicz M. Hughes E. Creswell P. Spies T. Nature. 1992; 360: 171-174Google Scholar), and tumor cells (4Ehrlich R. Immunol. Res. 1995; 14: 77-97Google Scholar, 11Restifo N.P. Esquivel F. Kawakami Y. Yewdell J.W. Mule J.J. Rosenberg S.A. Bennink J. J. Exp. Med. 1993; 177: 265-272Google Scholar, 12Rotem-Yehudar R. Winograd S. Sela S. Coligan J.E. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 180: 477-488Google Scholar), which do not express TAP genes, are generally devoid of cell surface MHC class I molecules. Cell lines and knockout mice lacking β2m expression also fail to display normal cell surface class I MHC molecules (13Williams D.B. Barber B.H. Flavell R.A. Allen H. J. Immunol. 1989; 142: 2796-2806Google Scholar, 14Zijlstra M. Bix M. Simister N.E. Loring J.M. Raulet D.H. Jaenisch R. Nature. 1990; 344: 742-746Google Scholar, 15Koller B.H. Marrack P. Kappler J.W. Smithies O. Science. 1990; 248: 1227-1230Google Scholar). The crucial role of β2m is evident from data demonstrating that it stabilizes cell surface expression of class I heavy chains, facilitates the binding of purified class I molecules to antigenic peptides both on cells and plastic surfaces, and generates additional high affinity peptide-binding sites in preparations of soluble purified class I molecules (16Rock K.L. Rothstein L.E. Gamble S.R. Benacerraf B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 7517-7521Google Scholar, 17Vitiello A. Potter T.A. Sherman L.A. Science. 1990; 250: 1423-1426Google Scholar, 18Rock K.L. Gamble S. Rothstein L. Benacerraf B Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 301-304Google Scholar, 19Kozlowski S. Takeshita T. Boehncke W.-H. Takahashi H. Boyd L.F. Germain R.N. Berzofsky J.A. Margulies D.H. Nature. 1991; 349: 74-77Google Scholar, 20Boyde L.F. Kozlowski S. Margulies D.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 2242-2250Google Scholar). These data, as well as the finding that β2m determines the fate of class I heavy chains (21Otten G.R. Bikoff E. Ribaudo R.K. Kozlowski S. Margulies D.H. Germain R. J. Immunol. 1992; 148: 3723-3732Google Scholar), suggest that β2m may play a predominant role in maintaining the class I heavy chain in a non-denatured conformation suitable for terminal folding upon binding of peptide. Such a model predicts a role for extracellular β2m in providing a microenvironment that supports the existence of cell surface β2m/heavy chain dimers capable of binding peptides. Indeed, both constitutive and peptide-induced class I surface expression can be augmented markedly, in some cases, by the presence of exogenous β2m (21Otten G.R. Bikoff E. Ribaudo R.K. Kozlowski S. Margulies D.H. Germain R. J. Immunol. 1992; 148: 3723-3732Google Scholar, 22Abdel Motal U. Zhou M.X. Siddiqi A.R. Jondal M. Scand. J. Immunol. 1993; 38: 395-400Google Scholar). The existence of a substantial pool of inactive heavy chains on the cell surface, which are able to bind added β2m at 37°C, has been demonstrated by Rock et al. (23Rock K.L. Gamble S. Rothstein L. Gramm C. Benacerraf B. Cell. 1991; 65: 611-620Google Scholar), implying a physiological role for exogenous β2m in maintaining cell surface class I heavy chains in a state suitable for subsequent binding of exogenous peptides. Increased levels of β2m can be detected both in the peripheral circulation and locally, in many abnormal in vivo conditions (24Manicourt D. Brauman H. Orloff S. Ann. Rheum. Dis. 1978; 37: 328-332Google Scholar, 25Maury C.P.J. Helve T. Sjoblom C. Rheumatol. Int. 1982; 2: 145-149Google Scholar, 26Child J.A. Spati B. Illingworth S. Cancer. 1980; 45: 318-326Google Scholar, 27Goldman M.H. Landwehr D.M. Lippman R. Transplant. Proc. 1982; 14: 437-439Google Scholar, 28Beorcia S. Vincent C. Revillard J.P. Clin. Chim. Acta. 1981; 109: 245-255Google Scholar). Additionally, lymphoid and hepatoma cells have been shown to produce and secrete β2m when stimulated with various cytokines (29Hoffmann B. Baas H. Nishanian P. Faisal M. Figlin R.A. Sarna G.P. Fahey J.L. Clin. Exp. Immunol. 1992; 88: 548-554Google Scholar, 30Homma T. Tsujinaka T. Kido Y. Yasuda T. Murata A. Mori T. Eur. Surg. Res. 1992; 24: 204-210Google Scholar). If these augmented levels facilitate the accumulation of class I-bound peptides, then the regulation of β2m secretion may have functional consequences. Supportive of such a role are data demonstrating the strong in vivo priming of cytotoxic T-lymphocytes to class I-binding peptides if the latter are combined with β2m when injected into mice (31Rock K.L. Fleischacker C. Gamble S. J. Immunol. 1993; 150: 1244-1252Google Scholar). We have shown previously that, in primary embryonal fibroblasts from transgenic mice expressing both endogenous H-2 genes and a miniature swine class I transgene (PD1), transformation with the highly oncogenic Ad12 results in inhibition of the transport of newly synthesized class I molecules via the Golgi apparatus, a significant reduction in peptide transporter (TAP1 and TAP2) and in proteasome-associated (LMP2 and LMP7) gene expression, and in suppression of cell surface expression of all class I antigens (12Rotem-Yehudar R. Winograd S. Sela S. Coligan J.E. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 180: 477-488Google Scholar, 32Shemesh J. Rotem-Yehudar R. Ehrlich R. J. Virol. 1991; 65: 5544-5548Google Scholar, 33Shemesh J. Ehrlich R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15704-15711Google Scholar, 34Rotem-Yehudar R. Groettrup M. Soza A. Kloetzel P.-M. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1996; 183: 499-514Google Scholar). Expression of these class I genes is either normal or up-regulated in cells transformed by the non-oncogenic virus-Ad5. Re-expression of TAP and LMP in an Ad12-transformed cell line completely reconstituted the cell surface expression and transport of PD1 and induced the transport of 20% of the H-2Db molecules, but did not affect the transport or expression of H-2Kb molecules (34Rotem-Yehudar R. Groettrup M. Soza A. Kloetzel P.-M. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1996; 183: 499-514Google Scholar). These data, as well as the fact that in Ad12-transformed cells, H-2 molecules were not recognized by conformation-independent antibodies (33Shemesh J. Ehrlich R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15704-15711Google Scholar, 34Rotem-Yehudar R. Groettrup M. Soza A. Kloetzel P.-M. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1996; 183: 499-514Google Scholar), raised the possibility that either the synthesis of β2m in these cells is defective and the class I heavy chains compete for a limited amount of β2m molecules (PD1 being more competitive), or that Ad12-transformed cells are deficient in a factor(s) that facilitate the assembly of β2m with a particular set of class I heavy chains (H-2). We now present data substantiating that β2m, as well as H-2Db and H-2Kb, are transcribed and translated in Ad12-transformed cells. However, the results show an abnormal turnover of β2m molecules and suggest the existence of a novel β2m-binding molecule(s) that acts to retain β2m in the transformed cells. The Ad12-transformed (VAD12.79, VAD12.42, VAD12.20, VAD12.25, VAD12.36, VAD12.54, and VAD12.43), E1Ad5-transformed (A5O1 and A5O5), and TAP-transfected cell lines and the normal cell line M1 have been described previously (32Shemesh J. Rotem-Yehudar R. Ehrlich R. J. Virol. 1991; 65: 5544-5548Google Scholar, 33Shemesh J. Ehrlich R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15704-15711Google Scholar, 34Rotem-Yehudar R. Groettrup M. Soza A. Kloetzel P.-M. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1996; 183: 499-514Google Scholar). Cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 2 mM glutamine, 10% fetal calf serum, penicillin, streptomycin, gentamycin, and amphotericin B at the recommended concentrations (35Jacoby W.B. Pastan I.H. Methods Enzymol. 1979; 58: 110-116Google Scholar). Media and supplements were purchased from Biological Industries (Bet Ha'emek, Israel). Cell lines were treated with 600 units/ml α/β interferons (Lee Biomolecular Research Inc., San Diego, CA) for 16 h, or 100 units/ml γ-interferon (Boehringer, Mannheim, Germany) for 48 h before harvesting. TAP2-transfected Ad12-transformed cells (VAD12.79 Cl1.1, 34Rotem-Yehudar R. Groettrup M. Soza A. Kloetzel P.-M. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1996; 183: 499-514Google Scholar) were transfected by the calcium phosphate-DNA coprecipitation method (34Rotem-Yehudar R. Groettrup M. Soza A. Kloetzel P.-M. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1996; 183: 499-514Google Scholar). The transfection mixture contained 10 μg of plasmid DNA (the β2m gene expressed from an actin promoter in PBr was constructed in Dr. D. Margulies' laboratory (NIAID, NIH, Bethesda, MD)), 1 μg of plasmid DNA containing the hygromycin gene, and 5 μg of carrier DNA (sheared salmon sperm DNA, Sigma). Twenty-four hours after transfection, the cells were washed with PBS, fresh media was added and after an additional 24 h the medium was supplemented with 110 units/ml hygromycin B (Calbiochem). Following selection of hygromycin-resistant cells, individual cell colonies were isolated and expanded in culture. The following antibodies were used for immunoprecipitation: 20.8.4S (recognizes the α1/α2 epitope on H-2Kb; 36Ozato K. Sachs D.H. J. Immunol. 1981; 126: 317-321Google Scholar); B22.249 (recognizes an α1 epitope on H-2Db; 36Ozato K. Sachs D.H. J. Immunol. 1981; 126: 317-321Google Scholar); PT85A (recognizes a public determinant on swine lymphocyte antigens (SLA); 37Davis W.C. Marusic S. Lewin H.A. Splitter G.A. Perryman L.E. McGuire T.C. Gorham J.R. Vet. Immunol. Immunopathol. 1987; 15: 337-376Google Scholar). Rabbit antibodies directed against β2m were a kind gift from Dr. J. E. Coligan (NIAID, NIH, Bethesda, MD). Cells were grown to 80% confluence and starved for 15 min in methionine-free medium. They were then labeled in methionine-free medium containing 250 mCi/ml [35S]methionine (Amersham International, Little Chalfort, United Kingdom (UK)) for 15 min unless otherwise indicated, washed with PBS, and chased for the indicated intervals. Cells that were labeled for 15 h were incubated in methionine-free medium containing 16% Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum and 100 mCi/ml [35S]methionine. The cells were lysed with buffer containing 0.5% Triton X-100, 50 mM Tris (pH 7.5), and 150 mM NaCl. The immunoprecipitates were washed with buffer containing 0.1% Triton X-100, 50 mM Tris (pH 7.5), and 150 mM NaCl. For Endo H treatment, immunoprecipitates were eluted by adding 25 μl containing 50 mM Tris (pH 8), 1% SDS, and boiled for 5 min. The samples were centrifuged and the supernatant was added to 25 μl of 50 mM citrate buffer (pH 5.5) containing 500 units of Endo H (New England Biolabs). The samples were incubated at 37°C for 18 h, followed by the addition of sample buffer. All the buffers contained the following protease inhibitors; 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 10 μg/ml aprotinin, 10 μg/ml leupeptin (Sigma). The immunoprecipitates were fractionated on 10 or 15% SDS-polyacrylamide gels, and X-Omat AR x-ray films (Eastman Kodak Co.) were exposed to the dried gels. Membranes were prepared as described (38New YorkColigan J.E. Kruisbeek A.M. Margulies D. Shevach E.M. Strober W. Current Protocols in Immunology. John Wiley μ Sons, New York1994: 81.2-8.1.5Google Scholar). Briefly, cell lysates were separated into two fractions: one containing cell membranes and the other containing soluble proteins. Cell pellets (5 × 107/ml) were resuspended in ice-cold Dounce buffer (10 mM Tris (pH 7.6), 0.5 mM MgCl) with protein inhibitors and incubated on ice for 30 min. The cells were lysed with a Dounce homogenizer, and the tonicity of the solution was restored by adding NaCl to a final concentration of 0.15 M. The suspension was spun at 500 × g to remove the nuclei, and the supernatant was further centrifuged for 45 min at 100,000 × g at 4°C. The supernatant, which contained soluble proteins, was transferred to a separate tube, and the pellet was resuspended in lysis buffer. The following probes have been described previously (32Shemesh J. Rotem-Yehudar R. Ehrlich R. J. Virol. 1991; 65: 5544-5548Google Scholar, 33Shemesh J. Ehrlich R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15704-15711Google Scholar, 34Rotem-Yehudar R. Groettrup M. Soza A. Kloetzel P.-M. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1996; 183: 499-514Google Scholar); the actin probe was a PstI-PstI fragment from chicken β actin cDNA, the PD1-specific probe was a SacI-BamHI genomic fragment containing exons 2-7 of the PD1 gene, the H-2 probe was an EcoRI-HindIII fragment derived from pH-2d33 (H-2Kd), the β2m probe was a PstI-PstI fragment from β2m cDNA, and the histone probe was a BamHI genomic fragment. Plasmids containing H-2Kb cDNA and H-2Db genomic (pMo/Db) fragments (40Levitsky H.I. Lazenby A. Hayashi R.J. Pardoll D.M. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 179: 1215-1224Google Scholar) were used as templates for PCR reactions and were a kind gift from Dr. L. Eisenbach (The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel) and from Dr. D. Pardoll (Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD), respectively. The hybridization solution contained 4 × SSC, 50% formamide, 0.2% SDS, 0.1% polyvinylpyrrolidone, and 100 μg/ml sheared salmon sperm DNA. Hybridizations were carried out at 42°C, followed by washes with 2 × SSC, 0.1% SDS at room temperature, and 0.2 × SSC at temperatures ranging between 55 and 65°C. After stripping with a boiling solution of 0.1% SDS, the blots were used for additional hybridizations. Cytoplasmic RNA was prepared using a modification of the White and Bancroft method (41White B.A. Bancroft F.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 8569-8572Google Scholar), as described previously (34Rotem-Yehudar R. Groettrup M. Soza A. Kloetzel P.-M. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1996; 183: 499-514Google Scholar). RNA was denatured and fractionated on a 1.2% formaldehyde/formamide agarose gel, blotted onto a Hybond-N membrane (Amersham International, Little Chalfort, UK) and hybridized with the appropriate probe, which had been labeled with [α-32P]dCTP (Rotem Industries, Dimona, Israel), using a Random Priming labeling kit (U. S. Biochemical Corp.). Polysomes were fractionated as described previously (42Meyuhas O. Thompson Jr., E.A. Perry R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1987; 7: 2691-2699Google Scholar). Cells were grown to 80% confluence and harvested by trypsinization (0.25 M trypsin EDTA; Biological Industries, Israel). A quantity of 6 × 107 cells was lysed per fractionation. The cells were washed with PBS, and cell pellets were kept at −70°C until used. Trypsin, PBS, and media contained 100 μg/ml cycloheximide (Sigma). Cells were thawed on ice and suspended in 450 μl of polysomal buffer containing 10 mM NaCl, 10 mM Tris (pH 7.4), 1.5 mM MgCl2, and 50 μl of ribonucleoside vanadyl complexes (200 mM) (New England Biolabs). Cells were lysed following the addition of 60 μl of polysomal buffer containing 10% Triton X-100 and 10% deoxycholate by brief mixing before and after 3 min of incubation on ice. Nuclei were pelleted by centrifugation for 3 min at 4°C, and the postnuclear supernatant was diluted with an equal volume of 25 mM Tris (pH 7.5), 10 mM MgCl2, 25 mM NaCl, 0.14 M sucrose, 500 μg/ml heparin, 0.05% Triton X-100. The suspension was layered over 35 ml of 15-45% (w/w) sucrose gradient with a 2-ml cushion of 45% sucrose. The sucrose solution contained 25 mM Tris (pH 7.5), 25 ml of NaCl, 2 mM MgCl2. A volume of 36 μl of heparin (from a stock solution of 200 μg/ml) was added to each gradient. The gradients were centrifuged at 26,000 rpm for 4 h at 4°C in a Beckman SW27 rotor. After centrifugation, 38 fractions of 1 ml each were collected into tubes containing 10 μl of 10% SDS. The A260 was monitored, the polysome profile was determined, and each 2-3 tubes were pooled to give a total of 8-10 tubes. RNA was extracted from polysomal and subpolysomal fractions as described before. Only gradients with identical polysomal profiles were compared. Reverse transcription of RNA was carried out for 1 h at 42°C, in 20 μl of PCR buffer II (Perkin Elmer) containing 1 μg of total cellular RNA, 2.5 μM oligo(dT)18 primer (New England Biolabs), 1 mM nucleotide mixture, 5 mM MgCl2, 35 units of ribonuclease inhibitor (MBI Fermentas, Vilnius, Lithuania), and 7 units of avian myeloblastosis virus reverse trascriptase (Promega, Madison, WI). The cDNA was stored at −20°C until used. PCR was carried out with 1 μl of the cDNA, and 50 pmol of the following primers (40Levitsky H.I. Lazenby A. Hayashi R.J. Pardoll D.M. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 179: 1215-1224Google Scholar): a 5′ consensus primer for H-Db and H-2Kb (5′-CGC GAC GCT GCT GCG CAC AG-3′), and 3′ primers specific for H-2Db (5′-TAC AAT CTC GGA GAG ACA TT-3′) or H-2Kb (5′-TAC AAT CTG GGA GAG ACA GA-3′), 40 μM nucleotide mixture, and 0.375 units of Taq DNA polymerase (Promega). Each PCR cycle included 1 min of denaturation at 94°C, 1 min of annealing at 65°C, and 1 min of extension/synthesis at 72°C. After the appropriate number of PCR cycles (MiniCycler, MJ Research Inc., Watertown, MA), 10 μl or less of the reaction mix were fractionated on a 1% agarose gel. The gel was soaked twice for 20 min in 1.5 M NaCl, 0.5 M NaOH at room temperature and blotted onto a Hybond-N membrane (Amersham International, Little Chalfort, UK) with transfer buffer containing 1.5 M NaCl, 0.25 M NaOH. The membrane was baked for 10 min at 80°C, and the DNA was cross-linked to the membrane by exposure to UV. Since both genes yield an RT-PCR product that is identical in size, two positive and two negative controls were included in each set of reactions. A plasmid containing a genomic fragment from H-2Db was amplified with H-2Db primers and with H-2Kb primers, and a plasmid containing H-2Kb cDNA was amplified with H-2Kb primers and with H-2Db primers. Since the yield of the PCR product is proportional to the starting amount of the template, only under conditions in which PCR amplification proceeds exponentially at a constant efficiency (43Moonan K.E. Beck C. Holzmayer T.A. Chin J.E. Wunder J.S. Andruilis I.L. Gazdar A.F. Willman C.L. Griffin B. Von Hoff D.D. Robinson I.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 7160-7164Google Scholar, 44Chelly J. Kaplan J.-C. Maire P. Gautron S. Kahn A. Nature. 1988; 333: 858-860Google Scholar) is the PCR reaction quantitative. A titration curve for amplified cDNA from each cell line and for each gene was plotted to ensure that the number of amplification cycles was below the plateau level. Detailed analysis of the results is presented under “Results.” Dried radioactive gels or blots were exposed to a phosphoimager screen and analyzed with a phosphoimager (Fuji BAS1000, Tokyo, Japan). The data are presented as phosphostimulated luminescence (PSL) units. In some cases, following scanning densitometric analysis of the x-ray films was performed. Due to post-transcriptional interference with class I assembly and transport (32Shemesh J. Rotem-Yehudar R. Ehrlich R. J. Virol. 1991; 65: 5544-5548Google Scholar, 33Shemesh J. Ehrlich R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15704-15711Google Scholar), most of the Ad12-transformed cell lines express very low levels of cell surface class I antigens despite having near normal levels of class I mRNA. Fig. 1 (A and B) substantiates previous data from our laboratory (12Rotem-Yehudar R. Winograd S. Sela S. Coligan J.E. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 180: 477-488Google Scholar, 32Shemesh J. Rotem-Yehudar R. Ehrlich R. J. Virol. 1991; 65: 5544-5548Google Scholar), demonstrating that nearly all the Ad12-transformed cell lines express normal or elevated levels of the miniature swine class I transgene (PD1) mRNA, and a normal level or less than a 2-fold reduction in H-2 mRNA, as compared with that in the normal cell lines as exemplified by M1. The level of class I mRNA in E1Ad5-transformed cells is either normal or enhanced. Full restoration of cell surface expression level and transport of PD1 was achieved by re-expression of peptide transporter molecules in the Ad12-transformed cell line VAD12.79 (12Rotem-Yehudar R. Winograd S. Sela S. Coligan J.E. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 180: 477-488Google Scholar) but the expression level of H-2Db was only partially restored, and the expression level of H-2Kb remained very low in these TAP-reconstituted and in TAP+LMP-reconstituted cells (12Rotem-Yehudar R. Winograd S. Sela S. Coligan J.E. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 180: 477-488Google Scholar, 34Rotem-Yehudar R. Groettrup M. Soza A. Kloetzel P.-M. Ehrlich R. J. Exp. Med. 1996; 183: 499-514Google Scholar). In order to examine whether the selective suppression of H-2Kb expression was mediated by H-2Kb-specific gene regulatory elements, the mRNA levels of the individual H-2 genes were analyzed in the transformed cells. Since efficient detection and quantitation of H-2 mRNA by Northern blot analysis requires a probe that does not distinguish H-2K from H-2D mRNA, we utilized a quantitative RT-PCR assay in order to determine the relative amounts of mRNA encoded by each of these genes. A total of 5-30 PCR cycles were performed for each of the cDNAs that were reverse-transcribed from total RNA. The PCR products were fractionated on agarose gels, blotted, hybridized to an H-2 probe, and the radioactive signal was quantitated, following various exposure periods. Fig. 2A shows the results of the analyses of H-2 cDNA in one of the transformed cell lines, using specific primers for H-2Kb and H-2Db. The primers were complementary to the same region in the two genes, thus minimizing possible differences that could result from DNA positioning or conformation. Since both sets of primers gave a band of the same size, the specificity of the PCR reaction was proved by the generation of the expected bands, using H-2Kb and H-2Db plasmid DNA templates (Fig. 2B). Analysis of the data showed a linear response curve when the number of PCR cycles ranged between 10 and 25. Similar response curves were obtained for E1Ad5-transformed (A5O1 and A5O5), Ad12-transformed (VAD12.79 and VAD12.42), and the normal cell line M1. Using the linear part of the curves, we compared the mRNA levels for each of the genes in the different cell lines. A representative display of the results is shown in Fig. 2B. The ratios in the levels between H-2Kb and H-2Db were determined, and the values are presented in Table I. These analyses showed that in Ad12-transformed, as well as in the normal and E1Ad5-transformed cell lines the ratio between H-2Kb and H-2Db transcripts is about 1, implying that the level of H-2D and H-2K mRNA is about the same. Thus, in Ad12-transformed cells H-2Kb is not selectively suppressed at the transcriptional level.Fig. 2Comparison of steady state level of H-2Kb and H-2Db mRNA as determined by RT-PCR in normal and Ad-transformed cell lines. RT-PCR was carried out using primers specific for H-2Kb and H-2Db. PCR products were fractionated on agarose gels, blotted onto nylon membranes, and hybridized with an H-2 probe. The single-stranded DNA-binding protein (SSB) of Bacillus subtilis phage φ29 is absolutely required for viral DNA replication in vivo. About ∼95% of the intrinsic tyrosine fluorescence of φ29 SSB is quenched upon binding to ssDNA, making tyrosine residues strong candidates to be directly involved in complex formation with ssDNA. Thus, we have studied the spectroscopic properties of the φ29 SSB tyrosines (Tyr-50, Tyr-57, and Tyr-76) using steady-state and time-resolved fluorescence measurements. φ29 SSB tyrosines do not seem to be highly restricted by strong interactions with neighbor residues, as suggested by (i) the high value of the average quantum yield of the φ29 SSB fluorescence emission (φF = 0.067 ± 0.010), (ii) the fast motions of the tyrosine side chains (φshort = 0.14 ± 0.06 ns), and (iii) the lack of tyrosinate emission at neutral pH. Stern-Volmer analysis of the quenching by acrylamide and I− indicates that φ29 SSB tyrosines are surrounded by a negatively charged environment and located in a relatively exposed protein domain, accessible to the solvent and, likely, to ssDNA. Changes in the intrinsic fluorescence upon ssDNA binding allowed us to determine that temperature has an opposite effect on the thermodynamic parameters K (intrinsic binding constant) and ω(cooperativity) defining φ29 SSB-poly(dT) interaction, the effective DNA binding constant, Keff = Kω, being largely independent of temperature. Altogether, the fluorescent properties of φ29 SSB tyrosines are consistent with a direct participation in complex formation with ssDNA. The single-stranded DNA-binding protein (SSB) of Bacillus subtilis phage φ29 is absolutely required for viral DNA replication in vivo. About ∼95% of the intrinsic tyrosine fluorescence of φ29 SSB is quenched upon binding to ssDNA, making tyrosine residues strong candidates to be directly involved in complex formation with ssDNA. Thus, we have studied the spectroscopic properties of the φ29 SSB tyrosines (Tyr-50, Tyr-57, and Tyr-76) using steady-state and time-resolved fluorescence measurements. φ29 SSB tyrosines do not seem to be highly restricted by strong interactions with neighbor residues, as suggested by (i) the high value of the average quantum yield of the φ29 SSB fluorescence emission (φF = 0.067 ± 0.010), (ii) the fast motions of the tyrosine side chains (φshort = 0.14 ± 0.06 ns), and (iii) the lack of tyrosinate emission at neutral pH. Stern-Volmer analysis of the quenching by acrylamide and I− indicates that φ29 SSB tyrosines are surrounded by a negatively charged environment and located in a relatively exposed protein domain, accessible to the solvent and, likely, to ssDNA. Changes in the intrinsic fluorescence upon ssDNA binding allowed us to determine that temperature has an opposite effect on the thermodynamic parameters K (intrinsic binding constant) and ω(cooperativity) defining φ29 SSB-poly(dT) interaction, the effective DNA binding constant, Keff = Kω, being largely independent of temperature. Altogether, the fluorescent properties of φ29 SSB tyrosines are consistent with a direct participation in complex formation with ssDNA. Interactions of nucleic acids and proteins provide the structural framework for a wide variety of biological processes. Among them, complexes formed by the association of single-stranded DNA-binding proteins (SSBs) 1The abbreviations used are: SSB(s)single-stranded DNA-binding protein(s)5-MeOI5-methoxyindoleNAcTyrAN-acetyl-L-tyrosine amidentnucleotide(s)ssDNAsingle-stranded DNAPf3 phagePseudomonas aeruginosa filamentous bacteriophage. with single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) are of particular interest. First, they modulate key processes of DNA metabolism: DNA replication and DNA repair (1Kornberg A. Baker T.A. Kornberg A. Baker T.A. DNA Replication. Freeman and Co., San Francisco1992: 323-354Google Scholar, 2Kneale G.G. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 1992; 2: 124-130Google Scholar), transcription and translation regulation (3Mukherjee R. Chambon P. Nucleic Acids Res. 1990; 18: 5713-5716Google Scholar, 4Michel B. Zinder N.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 4002-4006Google Scholar), and recombination (5Meyer R.R. Laine P.S. Microbiol. Rev. 1990; 54: 342-380Google Scholar, 6Moore S.P. Erdile T. Kelly T. Fishel R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci U. S. A. 1991; 88: 9067-9071Google Scholar, 7Alani E. Thresher R. Griffith J.D. Kolodner R.D. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 227: 54-71Google Scholar). Second, although all SSBs bind ssDNA with high affinity, the functional outcome of this interaction could be radically different. Thus, while most of them activate DNA replication, e.g. Escherichia coli SSB, T4 gp32, T7 gene 2.5 protein, φ29 SSB, RP-A (reviewed in 1Kornberg A. Baker T.A. Kornberg A. Baker T.A. DNA Replication. Freeman and Co., San Francisco1992: 323-354Google Scholar), some SSBs are inhibitory. Thus, SSBs of filamentous phages M13, fd and f1 or Pf3 block DNA replication by preventing the conversion of the viral strand into the replicative form (8Salstrom J.S. Pratt D. J. Mol. Biol. 1971; 61: 489-501Google Scholar). Third, detailed structural studies of a few SSBs have revealed that virtually each SSB interacts with DNA using a characteristic and largely specific set of contacts (9Casas-Finet J.R. Karpel R.L. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 9735-9744Google Scholar, 10Skinner M.M. Zhang H. Leschintzer D.H. Guan Y. Bellamy H. Sweet R. Gray C.W. Konings R.N.H. Wang A.H.J. Terwingler T.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 2071-2075Google Scholar, 11Folmer R.H.A. Nilges M. Folkers P.J.M. Konings R.N.H. Hilbers C.W. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 240: 341-357Google Scholar, 12Folmer R.H.A. Nilges M. Konings R.N.H. Hilbers C.W. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 4132-4142Google Scholar, 13Shamoo Y. Friedman A.M. Parsons M.R. Konisberg W.H. Steitz T.A. Nature. 1995; 376: 362-366Google Scholar). As a consequence of this diversity, the molecular nature of the SSB-DNA interactions are less understood than those occurring with double-stranded DNA-binding proteins. single-stranded DNA-binding protein(s) 5-methoxyindole N-acetyl-L-tyrosine amide nucleotide(s) single-stranded DNA Pseudomonas aeruginosa filamentous bacteriophage. Bacillus subtilis phage φ29 DNA replication requires a SSB. In vivo, the elongation process of DNA replication is dependent on the expression of a virally-encoded SSB protein, φ29 SSB (reviewed in 14Salas M. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1991; 60: 39-71Google Scholar and 15Salas M. Freire R. Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Méndez J. Bravo A. Serrano M. Blasco M.A. Blanco L. Gutiérrez C. Hermoso J.M. FEMS Microbiol. Rev. 1995; 17: 73-82Google Scholar), the cellular SSB being apparently unable to support φ29 DNA replication. In vitro, φ29 SSB is essential to obtain full-length φ29 DNA when the amount of DNA used as template is low (16Blanco L. Lázaro J.M. de Vega M. Bonnin A. Salas M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 12198-12202Google Scholar), the closest condition to the initial steps of viral infection. Even when the amount of DNA template is high, φ29 SSB is important for the in vitro system, increasing several times dNTP incorporation (17Martín G. Lázaro J.M. Méndez E. Salas M. Nucleic Acids. Res. 1989; 17: 3663-3672Google Scholar, 18Gutiérrez C. Martín G. Sogo J.M. Salas M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 2104-2111Google Scholar). This stimulatory effect is related to binding to the ssDNA produced during φ29 DNA replication (19Gutiérrez C. Sogo J.M. Salas M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 222: 983-994Google Scholar), which, likely, protects it from nuclease degradation and prevents unproductive binding of the φ29 DNA polymerase. φ29 SSB also disrupts, by its helix-destabilizing activity, the secondary structure formed in ssDNA parts of φ29 replicative intermediates. This activity has been proposed to account for the stimulation of the DNA elongation velocity by φ29 DNA polymerase under conditions in which the DNA opening is impaired (20Soengas M.S. Gutiérrez C. Salas M. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 253: 517-529Google Scholar). The thermodynamic parameters defining φ29 SSB-ssDNA complex formation have been recently described: it binds to ssDNA with relatively low affinity (Keff = 105M−1) and moderate cooperativity (ω= 50-70), covering 3-4 nt per monomer, probably as a single array of protein units along the DNA (21Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar). However, the precise mechanism that accounts for the requirement of φ29 SSB during viral DNA replication is still unknown. The lack of significant sequence homology with other SSBs (18Gutiérrez C. Martín G. Sogo J.M. Salas M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 2104-2111Google Scholar) has made difficult the identification of the φ29 SSB domain(s) responsible for DNA binding and protein-protein contacts that lead to a stable protein-DNA interaction. Interestingly, complex formation occurs with significant alterations in the intrinsic tyrosine fluorescence of φ29 SSB. Thus, 95% of the protein fluorescence is quenched upon binding (21Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar), this value being one of the highest reported for a SSB, and similar to that observed for proteins that bind DNA through direct interactions with tyrosine residues (22Härd T. Hsu V. Sayre M.H. Geidusecheck E.P. Appelt K. Kearns D.R. Biochemistry. 1984; 28: 396-406Google Scholar). If the three tyrosines of φ29 SSB (at positions 50, 57, and 76) were in fact forming part of the domain directly involved in ssDNA complex organization, they should not be highly restricted by interactions with other neighboring residues and, likely, placed in an accessible domain of the protein. To test this possibility, we have characterized the global spectroscopic properties of the tyrosines of φ29 SSB by using complementary approaches: (i) steady-state and time-resolved measurements of the total emission and anisotropy of φ29 SSB fluorescence, (ii) analysis of the resistance of φ29 SSB tyrosines to undergo ionization by pH increase, and (iii) selective attenuation of the tyrosine fluorescence by small diffusible quenchers. In addition, the fluorescent properties of φ29 SSB were also considered to study ssDNA binding under different temperatures. Our results regarding the mobility and accessibility of φ29 SSB tyrosines strongly suggest a direct role of these residues in complex formation. In the accompanying paper (23Soengas M.S. Mateo C.R. Rivas G. Salas M. Acuña A.U. Gutiérrez C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 303-310Google Scholar), some of the fluorescence features of φ29 SSB tyrosines are combined with other spectroscopic and hydrodynamic studies, to model the conformational properties of φ29 SSB and the effect of complex formation on both φ29 SSB and ssDNA structure. All the solutions were made with distilled, deionized (MilliQ) and sterilized water, and finally filtered through 0.45-μm filters using a Millex-HA Filter Unit (Millipore). The buffer used in time-resolved fluorescence analysis was 5 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5 (20°C) (buffer A), while the buffer used in absorption and steady-state fluorescence studies was 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5 (20°C), 4% glycerol (buffer B). Poly(dT) was from Pharmacia Biotech Inc. φ29 SSB was purified by differential ammonium sulfate fractionation of φ29-infected cellular extracts followed by phosphocellulose and DEAE-cellulose chromatography, essentially as described (20Soengas M.S. Gutiérrez C. Salas M. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 253: 517-529Google Scholar). Protein concentration was estimated by the Lowry (24Lowry O.H. Rosebrough N.J. Farr A.L. Randall R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1951; 193: 265-275Google Scholar) method, using bovine serum albumin as a standard. Absorption spectra were carried out in a CARY 219 (Varian) at a constant temperature of 22°C with cells of path-lengths from 2 to 10 mm. Measurements of the intrinsic tyrosine fluorescence of φ29 SSB were recorded, unless otherwise stated, at 22°C. Fluorescence excitation and emission spectra, solute quenching experiments, as well as ssDNA binding assays were performed in a Schoeffel Instrument Corp. RRS100 spectrofluorimeter (slits set to 2 nm), with a 2-mm path-length cell, and corrected for residual emission of the buffers. Fluorescence quantum yield and fluorescence emission anisotropy measurements were carried out in a SLM-8000D photon counting fluorimeter fitted with Glan-Thompson polarizers. The excitation and emission slits were 4 and 8 nm, respectively. When necessary, corrections for wavelength dependence of the instrument response were taken into account as described elsewhere (25Acuña A.U. González J. Lillo P. Otón J.M. Photochem. Photobiol. 1984; 40: 351-359Google Scholar). The steady-state average fluorescence quantum yield (φFST) of the protein was calculated as in Demas and Crosby (26Demas J.N. Crosby G.A. J. Phys. Chem. 1971; 75: 991-1024Google Scholar) using an aqueous solution of 5-methoxy-indole (5-MeOI) as reference (φREF = 0.28 ± 0.01; 27Hersberger M.V. Lumry R.W. Photochem. Photobiol. 1976; 23: 391-397Google Scholar). Magic angle orientation of the polarizers was selected to avoid anisotropic effects (28Lakowicz J.R. Principles of Fluorescence Spectroscopy. Plenum Press, New York1983Google Scholar). The accessibility to solvent and the ionic environment of the fluorescent tyrosines of φ29 SSB were analyzed by monitoring the fluorescence quenching (λexc = 276 nm, λem = 308 nm) induced by adding increasing amounts of stock solutions (2.5 M) of neutral (acrylamide) or charged quenchers, I− (as KI) and Cs+ (as CsCl) to the protein sample (7-11 μM). To prevent iodide oxidation, and avoid light dispersion and chemical reactions (29Lehrer S.S. Biochemistry. 1971; 10: 3254-3263Google Scholar), Na2S2O3, at a final concentration of 200 μM, was added to the KI solution. Corrections for dilution and inner filter effect due to quencher absorption were made as described previously (21Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar). Data were analyzed by Stern-Volmer plots of F0/F versus [Q], where F0 and F stand for the fluorescence intensities in the absence and in the presence of quencher, respectively, and [Q] is the quencher concentration. Since these plots were linear, the “static” quenching contribution was considered <10% (see “Discussion”), and the Stern-Volmer constant, Ksv, could be directly obtained from the slope of the line (see 30Eftink M.R. Dewey T.G. Biophysical and Biochemical Applications of Fluorescence Spectroscopy. Plenum Press, New York1991: 1-41Google Scholar and 31Eftink M.R. Methods Biochem. Anal. 1991; 35: 127-205Google Scholar). This parameter represents the weighted sum of the individual constants of the emitting tyrosine residues and, therefore, is referred as Ksv,eff in the text. Ksv,eff was used to calculate the bimolecular rate constant of the quenching process, kq,eff, from the expression Ksv,eff = kq,eff·, where is the weighted average lifetime of φ29 SSB fluorescence (see below). The fractional accessibility of the tyrosine residues to quencher was also estimated from the y axis intercept of double reciprocal plots as proposed by Lehrer (29Lehrer S.S. Biochemistry. 1971; 10: 3254-3263Google Scholar; see also 30Eftink M.R. Dewey T.G. Biophysical and Biochemical Applications of Fluorescence Spectroscopy. Plenum Press, New York1991: 1-41Google Scholar, 31Eftink M.R. Methods Biochem. Anal. 1991; 35: 127-205Google Scholar, 32Acuña A.U. López-Hernández F.J. Otón J.M. Biophys. Chem. 1982; 16: 253-260Google Scholar). The solid angle ω, under which the quencher can freely approach the tyrosine residues, was calculated as described (33Lux B. Gérard D. Laustriat G. FEBS Lett. 1977; 80: 66-70Google Scholar), taking the values of the diffusion constants of the acrylamide, the iodide ion and the tyrosyl residues as 2 × 10−5 cm2 s−1, 1.5 × 10−5 cm2 s−1, and 0, respectively (33Lux B. Gérard D. Laustriat G. FEBS Lett. 1977; 80: 66-70Google Scholar, 34Eftink M.R. Ghiron C.A. Biochemistry. 1976; 15: 672-680Google Scholar). N-Acetyl-L-tyrosine amide (NAcTyrA) was taken as a control for a fully accessible residue. The effect of temperature on complex formation with ssDNA was analyzed by monitoring the fluorescence intensity changes during direct titrations of a fixed amount of poly(dT), 30-40 μM (in nt), with increasing amounts of φ29 SSB as described previously (21Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar and references therein). The reaction buffer, buffer B, was adjusted to pH 7.5 at 20°C. Since in the temperature range analyzed (10-42°C) the pH variation (from pH 7.0 to 7.6) does not alter the global structural properties of φ29 SSB (see accompanying paper (23Soengas M.S. Mateo C.R. Rivas G. Salas M. Acuña A.U. Gutiérrez C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 303-310Google Scholar)), no pH readjustments were made during the binding measurements. The thermodynamic parameters, nucleotide site size, n, intrinsic affinity constant, K, and cooperativity, ω, were obtained by fitting the experimental data to the theoretical ones given by the McGhee and von Hippel's (35McGhee J.D. von Hippel P.H. J. Mol. Biol. 1974; 86: 469-489Google Scholar) equations for binding of proteins to large lattices with overlapping binding sites (see 21Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar, for further details). The enthalpy and the entropy of the binding process were approximated from the slope and the y axis intercept of the best fit of van't Hoff plots of lnKωversus 1/T, as −ΔHo/R and ΔSo/R (R being the gas constant), respectively, since the response was linear and therefore ΔCpo = 0. Enthalpy and entropy changes were calculated for the indicated buffer and protein concentrations, and therefore named as ΔHobso and ΔSobso throughout the text. To determine the steady-state fluorescence anisotropy, <r>, of φ29 SSB, the corresponding vertically (I∥) and horizontally (I∥) polarized emission intensities elicited by vertically polarized excitation were corrected for background scattering and included in the described equations for L-format geometry fluorimeters. Thus, <r> was obtained from the ratio (I∥− GI∥)/(I∥+ 2GI∥). The constant G, accounting for the differential polarization sensitivity of the photodetection set-up, was estimated as described previously (36Mateo C.R. Lillo M.P. González-Rodríguez J. Acuña A.U. Eur. Biophys. J. 1991; 20: 41-52Google Scholar). The protein concentration (10-15 μM) used was low enough to prevent turbidity of the solution and, therefore, light scattering that could result in an artifactual depolarization of the fluorescence (28Lakowicz J.R. Principles of Fluorescence Spectroscopy. Plenum Press, New York1983Google Scholar). The decay of total fluorescence intensity, measured at a magic angle orientation of the polarizers, and those of the parallel and perpendicular components were recorded at 22°C in a time-correlated single-photon counting spectrometer, as described (36Mateo C.R. Lillo M.P. González-Rodríguez J. Acuña A.U. Eur. Biophys. J. 1991; 20: 41-52Google Scholar), for a protein concentration ranging from 10 to 30 μM. The samples were excited at 290 ± 4 nm with vertically polarized light pulses from a thyratron-gated nanosecond flash lamp (Edimburg Instr. El 199) filled with N2. The emission was isolated with a cut-off 310 nm (Schott KV) and a band-pass U-54 (Schott) filters, and detected with a Phillips XP2020Q photomultiplier. The kinetic parameters (lifetimes τi, and amplitudes, αi) of the decay of the fluorescence intensity were determined by iterative convolution of the signal recorded at magic angle, I54(t). The fitting routines were based on non-linear least-squares techniques (37Knight A.E. Selinger B.K. Spectrochim. Acta. 1971; 27: 1223-1234Google Scholar, 38Grinvald A. Steinberg I.Z. Anal. Biochem. 1974; 59: 583-589Google Scholar), using standard weighting factors (39Wahl Ph Chem. Phys. 1976; 22: 245-256Google Scholar). Wavelength-dependent timing effects in the photodetection were corrected as indicated (36Mateo C.R. Lillo M.P. González-Rodríguez J. Acuña A.U. Eur. Biophys. J. 1991; 20: 41-52Google Scholar). The weighted average lifetime, , was computed from, τ¯=∑iαiτi(Eq. 1) The fluorescence quantum yield of Ï†29 SSB was also estimated by time-resolved techniques as the ratio /Ï„R, where Ï„R stands for the radiative lifetime of tyrosine, 27 Â± 2 ns (33Lux B. Gérard D. Laustriat G. FEBS Lett. 1977; 80: 66-70Google Scholar, 40Wu P. Li Y-K. Talalay P. Brand L. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 7415-7422Google Scholar). The fluorescence anisotropy decay parameters (rotational correlation times, Ï†i, and amplitudes, Î²i) were determined by simultaneously fitting the measured intensities Iâˆ¥, Iâˆ¥ to a sum of exponentials using a non-linear least-squares global analysis method as detailed elsewhere (36Mateo C.R. Lillo M.P. González-Rodríguez J. Acuña A.U. Eur. Biophys. J. 1991; 20: 41-52Google Scholar). The experimental decay of the tyrosine fluorescence anisotropy of Ï†29 SSB was best fitted to a biexponential function, roβ1e−t/ϕ1+βze−t/ϕ2,∑βi=1(Eq. 2) where ro is the anisotropy of the tyrosine emission at t = 0. The decay of the fluorescence intensity and anisotropy contains subnanosecond components that were not well resolved in the flash lamp spectrometer. To have a better definition of these parameters, a set of both kinds of measurements were also carried out at the Laboratoire of Biochimie Moleculaire et Cellulaire (Orsay, Paris) with a Ti:sapphire (Spectra Physics) ps laser spectrometer, tuned at the third harmonic (287 nm) and with an instrument response function of 75 ps; the tyrosine emission was detected at 308 and 315 nm (Δλ = 4 nm). To measure the tendency of the tyrosine phenolic hydroxyl groups of φ29 SSB to undergo ionization, small amounts of a stock solution of 2.5 M NaOH were added to a solution containing the indicated concentrations of protein in buffer B, the change in volume at the end of the titration being <2.5%. The pH increase was recorded simultaneously with the decrease in the fluorescence at 308 nm. Free tyrosine was taken as a model since its fluorescent properties depending on the ionic environment in response to pH increase are well documented (41Tanford C. Hauenstein J.D. Rands D.G. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1956; 77: 6409-6413Google Scholar, 42Sela M. Katchalski E. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1956; 78: 3986-3989Google Scholar, 43Searcy D.G. Montenay-Garestier T. Laston D.J. Hélène C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1988; 953: 321-333Google Scholar) and no equivalent data were, to our knowledge, available for NAcTyrA. Corrections for dilution and filter effects were made as described (21Soengas M.S. Esteban J.A. Salas M. Gutiérrez C. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 213-226Google Scholar). The amino acid sequence of φ29 SSB (Fig. 1A) was analyzed with currently available computer programs to assess its basic theoretical structural features. According to Chou-Fasman secondary structure predictions (44Chou P.Y. Fasman G.D. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1978; 47: 251-276Google Scholar), the region around tyrosines 50 and 57 (see Fig. 1A) showed a high probability of being in the protein surface. Moreover, analysis of the sequence-related hydropathy (45Pongor S. Guttieri M.J. Cohen L.M. Szalay A.A. DNA. 1985; 4: 319-326Google Scholar) indicated that this same region (from residues 49 to 69), based on the negative values of the Kyte-Doolittle index (Fig. 1B), could not be highly hydrophobic. In order to have a more reliable picture on both, the accessibility of the tyrosines of φ29 SSB to the solvent, and potentially to DNA, as well as their ionic environment, we analyzed the parameters defining the steady-state and the time-resolved intrinsic fluorescence properties of the φ29 SSB.
